prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for asking her not to drink?
I grew up with an abusive alcoholic mother.   It was hell and as a result I don’t drink at all and don’t like being around drunk people.  

When I started dating my girlfriend I knew that she drank and discussed my issues with it.  I just asked her that she doesn’t drink around me.  It worked out fine, she was great about not even drunk dialing me, a problem I had with my ex girlfriend.  

When we started discussing moving in I was very apprehensive about it.  I asked her if she could really handle not drinking at all in our home and she was adamant that it was no big deal.  That if she wanted to drink she could just spend that night at a friends and that she really didn’t drink that often anyways so it wouldn’t be a problem.  

The first few months that’s exactly what happened.  Since then though there have been times that she’s come home obviously drunk and just lying about it to me.  I’ve talked her about it to mixed reactions.  Sometimes she will apologize profusely and promise not to let it happen again.   Other times it becomes an argument about how I’m projecting my mother’s problem on our situation.  That she’s not an alcoholic or abusive.  Which is true, but it’s not really about her being abusive, it’s that being around drunk people drudges up a lot of painful memories for me.  She just brushed that off though.  

After this last time it happened she’s outright fighting me on the issue.   She says this is her home too and we’re both adults.   That I need to get therapy instead of trying to control her.  We had a clear agreement before we moved in though.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the AITA (Am I the Asshole) post is in the wrong. The situation is about the author's girlfriend drinking despite previous agreements.

So, the author has a history of growing up with an abusive alcoholic mother, which makes him uncomfortable around alcohol. He told his girlfriend from the start not to drink around him, and she agreed. When they moved in together, he asked her not to drink at home, and she said that's fine, she can go to friends' places if she wants to drink. Initially, that worked, but now she's coming home drunk and lying about it. The author is trying to talk to her, but she's defensive, saying he's projecting his mother's issues and that it's her home too. The author is frustrated because they had an agreement.

The user thinks the author is in the wrong, but wants my opinion. The options are A (yes, author is wrong) or B (no, author isn't wrong).

Hmm. Let me break it down. The author set boundaries early on, and the girlfriend agreed. She broke those agreements by drinking at home and lying. The author's trauma is valid, and he has a legitimate reason for his boundaries. The girlfriend is now disregarding those boundaries and being dismissive. The author isn't controlling; he's trying to protect his mental health. The girlfriend's response seems dismissive of his feelings and the initial agreement. So, from a boundary perspective, the author isn't in the wrong. The girlfriend is violating the agreed-upon terms and not respecting his needs. The author isn't being controlling, he's setting clear boundaries for his well-being. The girlfriend's actions are the issue here. So the answer would be B (author is not in the wrong). The user thought the author was wrong, but in this case, the author is justified in his requests and the girlfriend is not respecting them.
